so Canada's international development research centre idrc was established in
1970 so we just celebrated our 40th anniversary last year what we do is we
give research grants to developing country individuals and institutions to
investigate locally relevant issues so essentially it's it's finding out what are the issues that that are most
important and then finding ways with them to do some kind of Applied Research
that can get them the kind of evidence which might be able to get the kind of
influence that they're looking for so in effect trying to build new knowledge strengthening research

yes in large part we are we also get funding some amounts from other

so I'm gonna pause for a minute so that was a lot about health systems and specifically about IDRC supported work
in a health working through research networks so what I'm going to talk about
now is what I said I was going to talk about at the beginning which is monitoring and evaluation so before I go
on any questions so far nope okay
purposes of evaluation generally there are two major ones one is accountability
to see if you've done what you said you would do and to what extent you have or
haven't and another one is learning to figure out okay well this is what we wanted to do this is what happened what
can we learn from what actually happened from what we thought would happen and how can that improve what we might want
to do in the future and generally most evaluations are a mix of the two and if some might lean more towards
accountability others might lean more towards learning but generally there is some sort of a mix
these here I wanted to put up because they are the international standards of evaluation quality they were initiated
by the American evaluation Association but are now accepted pretty much internationally so the four standards
here are utility so it has to be useful essentially any evaluation you do you
have to make sure it's going to be used it should be feasible so it should it
should be something that is is possible to do within the that the time that you
have within the funding available etc the findings should be accurate so
accuracy is one of the one of the standards and propriety which deals with
issues of ethics so when you when you go about doing an evaluation to be sure that you follow you adhere to ethical
standards when you're doing stuff and here you have a cartoon that shows somebody with an indicator of 12 showing
it off and then someone else says oh well well that's fantastic but what does it mean so that whole idea that you can
have you always have to think about what is the use of what I'm doing and before
I get into UFE or any other specific approaches when evaluating I thought I'd
take a minute to just talk a little bit about monitoring and about monitoring and evaluation because often times
they're they're spoken about in the same breath you know you hear MD MD all the time and definitely they go hand in hand
because it's hard to do one without the other but there there is a distinction
monitoring tends to be something that happens throughout the lifecycle so you're gathering data throughout it's
something that's happening generally it's it's something that's done internally and it's meant to provide
that continuous feedback to help you report back on how something's performing to to learn how to improve
something whereas evaluation it's much more episodic and time-bound
the the amount of time that you spend to actually evaluate so when you're evaluating you're actually assessing the
value of something right so it's something that you're making a you're you're taking the data that you have available and
actually deciding something based on what you have and that that might be something that takes two weeks it might
be something that might take a year it really depends but it is it isn't just gathering the data it's knowing what you
want to do with it once you have it it can evaluation can be internal or
external and it's about periodic feedback so it doesn't happen it doesn't
rather have to happen just at the end which is more of a summative evaluation
it can be formative which happens throughout and it helps you improve what you want to do as you move forward or it
could be developmental which is something that is much more the the the
framing of what you're doing might even change based on what's what's happened around you so I'll talk about that more
so I just wanted to put that out there because I find sometimes people conflate monitoring with evaluation and you think
that when you have the data that you're doing the evaluation but you you really do need to know what you need to do with
it but at the same time you need to have the data there to to act on it some of
the key evaluation challenges for any evaluation is really clarifying the
values so I'm both in terms of values of the evaluator values of the the program
that you're looking at values of the respondents so just to be very clear about that trying not to compromise the the aspect
of learning because sometimes the word evaluation kind of instills fear in some and they think oh my goodness someone's
going to come here and judge me and I think I think it's it's it's a it's a moment of learning that's often lost
which is unfortunate because that can be a time that you can learn about what's happening and what you can do to make
things happen better another challenge is looking trying to establish a
cause-and-effect so correlations to find
them is is challenging it's not impossible but especially in an open system when things do not
thoroughly happen in a very linear way it can be challenging if you try to make them linear for the sake of evaluating
so that that can be a challenge measuring development results of research by definition when you're doing
research in a context that is resource constrained perhaps suffers from other
things like being prone to earthquakes or floods or have perhaps being in a post-conflict situation it is it's just
difficult sometimes to isolate out what is really happening and what's not so just to keep that in mind and that can
be a challenge and issues of timing timing both in the sense of having
enough time to evaluate what it is you want to do so keeping that in mind and
not just thinking at the end maybe this is what I want to do timing in terms of at what time within the life cycle of
what you're doing you want to begin to actually think about okay well I do want to learn about these things so maybe I
should start thinking about evaluation now instead of at the end and timing also in terms of the results that you
get from some of the interventions in terms of health information systems sometimes these interventions are maybe
a year maybe three years maybe five years but the actual development outcomes might happen you know ten years
down the line and and an example that's that's used a lot is the Tanzanian
essential health information program t-hub which happened over ten years ago
in Tanzania and IDRC did support that initial work and some of the some of the
outcomes in terms of the drop in mortality rates that happen some of it have been soon after but a lot of the
outcomes were not apparent until a long time afterwards so just to keep that in
mind in terms of what's feasible and knowing what what it is that you want to evaluate within the timeframe yes why

the main intended users they just assume it another one can be if when you're
identifying users you identify passive audiences so when when I talk about

users can also be challenging because organizations although they tend to have

of influence depending on who you work with if you work with the minister's cousin or something maybe it is but that
those kinds of those kinds of ideas of understanding what the flow of changes
are and then being able to understand so what are the kinds of changes that I might expect to see I might like to see
